text: Ryanair, Europe's largest airline.
We fly 3,300 flights every day.
Originally, we had AWS, our partner
for our data in the cloud,

but where they've really come
into their own is sharing

the vision with Ryanair
as to how we're going
to leverage generative AI.

We built our employee
app on Amazon Bedrock,
and it's been hugely successful
for the airline and its growth.
Crew can ask for questions.

They might ask what
are certain regulations

at certain times, and they can
access that through the app
and with that sort of generative AI,

and we're also meshing
in there a bot as well
that will get those answers back

to them rather than them
flicking through manuals,

and it also gives us a
willingness to change
and adapt our training.

It means that we're
able to plan our crews,
message our crews, get aircraft back

in the sky rather than having
to wait for those problems
to solve themselves,
and then we are transforming
our customer service at the moment.

One of the initiatives
that we've come up with is

with Amazon Connect for our
customer services center.

Now, that's putting in the
plumbing and the groundwork

and foundation so that we
can then use generative AI

to manage our cost base on
customer service handling
and do it more efficiently.

What AWS also delivers
for us is scalability,
both on the way up and on the way down,
and we've done a lot of that work
with various different applications

from an employee app that fits
into our rostering system,
takes over our messaging,
builds resilience in the system.
What building on AWS for Ryanair means,

what we're going to be
doing for the future.

If we're going to grow
by another 300 aircraft
and double the size of the airline,
we need the people in AWS to work with us,
and they work very closely with us,
whether it's on our employee app,

whether it's on leveraging
on customer service,
whether it's delivering that information

for our customers day to day
during times of disruption,
how search technology is going
to change over the next number of years

and how we can put together
more of the travel experience.
